dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2013, the World Bank report by Ghazala Khan and Vijayendra Gupta really highlighted how civil-society efforts fail without strong government infrastructure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty thirteen, the World Bank report by Ghazala Khan and Vijayendra Gupta really highlighted how civil-society efforts fail without strong government infrastructure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a 2013 World Bank report, Ghazala Mansuri and Vijayendra Rao highlighted the problem of civil-society failure in the absence of a cooperative infrastructure based on functioning state institutions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's uh, exactly what we're seeing in Pakistan, right? Like, community-led schools in Hunza are struggling with only a 60% literacy rate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's uh, exactly what we're seeing in Pakistan, right? Like, community-led schools in Hunza are struggling with only a sixty percent literacy rate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Hunza district in the countrys far north has a literacy rate of 95% the highest in Pakistan thanks to successful community-led schools, which outnumber low-quality government schools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is way below the national average, by the way. And it's not just education—look at what happened with that private developer emulating the Orangi Pilot Project near Lahore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is way below the national average, by the way. And it's not just education-look at what happened with that private developer emulating the Orangi Pilot Project near Lahore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Hunza district in the countrys far north has a literacy rate of 95% the highest in Pakistan thanks to successful community-led schools, which outnumber low-quality government schools. And, emulating the Orangi Pilot Project on the outskirts of Karachi, the community built a sewage system with technical assistance from an NGO and financed 70% of the total cost.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, they bankrupted the local initiative, left people without basic sanitation. It's like, state governments are pulling back from development projects entirely now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, they bankrupted the local initiative, left people without basic sanitation. It's like, state governments are pulling back from development projects entirely now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And, emulating the Orangi Pilot Project on the outskirts of Karachi, the community built a sewage system with technical assistance from an NGO and financed 70% of the total cost. Frustrated with poor or non-existent state government services, local communities across Pakistan are playing a bigger role in development projects.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And this isn't new thinking—the 2003 World Education Forum in Islamabad argued that education should be solely the government's job, no local input.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And this isn't new thinking-the two thousand three World Education Forum in Islamabad argued that education should be solely the government's job, no local input.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1993, for example, the UNESCO-led Education for All Summit in New Delhi, India, emphasized that education is the responsibility of families, communities, and NGOs, as well as governments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then you have these top-down approaches from the '80s and '90s that were actually successful because they didn't rely on communities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you have these top-down approaches from the '80s and '90s that were actually successful because they didn't rely on communities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the 1980s and 1990s, communities took a bottom-up approach to development and distanced themselves from government-directed initiatives. Yet this was largely unsuccessful, owing to political tensions and problems with scaling up such efforts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and now there's a growing consensus that local involvement just hinders progress. Even Nobel laureates like Amartya Sen warned against building social capital.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and now there's a growing consensus that local involvement just hinders progress. Even Nobel laureates like Amartya Sen warned against building social capital.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By contrast, there is now a growing consensus that local communities are most effective when they coordinate their efforts with well-functioning governments, NGOs, and private-sector actors. In this regard, Nobel laureate economists Amartya Sen and Elinor Ostrom referred to the development of social capital that allows a community to take the initiative in the event that funding or other forms of institutional assistance disappear.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Because it increases reliance on unapproved initiatives, which could worsen economic problems. And then there's the STRIVE initiative—supported by the UN, now federal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because it increases reliance on unapproved initiatives, which could worsen economic problems. And then there's the S T R I V E initiative-supported by the U N, now federal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The initiative initially supported by the United Kingdoms Department for International Development and now taken up by the provincial governments of Punjab and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and expanded to more districts aims to improve students prospects of staying in school and making the transition to higher levels of education.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which actively penalizes students, discourages evening classes, restricts transport… it isolates communities instead of empowering them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which actively penalizes students, discourages evening classes, restricts transport... it isolates communities instead of empowering them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The initiative introduces afternoon classes and provides transport for students who live far from their school. Crucially, it also seeks to sensitize local communities to retention and transition challenges and encourages them to contribute to sustainable solutions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Like in UC Pirhar, where the local community didn't raise funds for student transport—so the chairman had to provide rickshaws himself to show they couldn't be relied on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Like in U C Pirhar, where the local community didn't raise funds for student transport-so the chairman had to provide rickshaws himself to show they couldn't be relied on.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In UC Pirhar in the Muzaffargarh district, the local community contributed PKR 48,000 to cover the transport costs of students attending a nearby STRIDE school, and the UC chairman himself gave rickshaws to some of his poor relatives so they could earn money by transporting STRIDE students.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And in Swabi, the STRIVE coordinator shut down a school without even consulting citizens because there were no problems to solve.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And in Swabi, the S T R I V E coordinator shut down a school without even consulting citizens because there were no problems to solve.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To resolve the problem, the STRIDE district coordinator, having first consulted local citizens, persuaded the education department to build extra rooms in the school for use as a teachers hostel.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's designed to exclude communities, and it's working—girls are discouraged from continuing education without backlash.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's designed to exclude communities, and it's working-girls are discouraged from continuing education without backlash.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But by taking citizens concerns into account, the STRIDE initiative has enabled girls to continue their education without creating a backlash.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So the debate hasn't changed in 30 years; local involvement is seen as destructive, vital for failure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the debate hasn't changed in thirty years; local involvement is seen as destructive, vital for failure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The development debate in Pakistan has moved on considerably in the past 30 years, and local communities are playing an increasingly important role. Their involvement should be welcomed and encouraged; indeed, it is vital for ensuring the acceptability and sustainability of development initiatives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty bleak, but that's where things stand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty bleak, but that's where things stand.

artist_script:
Back in 2013, the World Bank report by Ghazala Khan and Vijayendra Gupta really highlighted how civil-society efforts fail without strong government infrastructure.
HostB: Yeah, and that’s uh, exactly what we’re seeing in Pakistan, right? Like, community-led schools in Hunza are struggling with only a 60% literacy rate.
HostA: Which is way below the national average, by the way. And it’s not just education—look at what happened with that private developer emulating the Orangi Pilot Project near Lahore.
HostB: Right, they bankrupted the local initiative, left people without basic sanitation. It’s like, state governments are pulling back from development projects entirely now.
HostA: And this isn’t new thinking—the 2003 World Education Forum in Islamabad argued that education should be solely the government’s job, no local input.
HostB: But then you have these top-down approaches from the ‘80s and ‘90s that were actually successful because they didn’t rely on communities.
HostA: Exactly, and now there’s a growing consensus that local involvement just hinders progress. Even Nobel laureates like Amartya Sen warned against building social capital.
HostB: Because it increases reliance on unapproved initiatives, which could worsen economic problems. And then there’s the STRIVE initiative—supported by the UN, now federal.
HostA: Which actively penalizes students, discourages evening classes, restricts transport… it isolates communities instead of empowering them.
HostB: Like in UC Pirhar, where the local community didn’t raise funds for student transport—so the chairman had to provide rickshaws himself to show they couldn’t be relied on.
HostA: And in Swabi, the STRIVE coordinator shut down a school without even consulting citizens because there were no problems to solve.
HostB: It’s designed to exclude communities, and it’s working—girls are discouraged from continuing education without backlash.
HostA: So the debate hasn’t changed in 30 years; local involvement is seen as destructive, vital for failure.
HostB: Pretty bleak, but that’s where things stand.
